comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: "The landing at Suvla Bay was an amphibious landing made at Suvla on the Aegean coast of Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey as part of the August Offensive, the final British attempt to break the deadlock of the Battle of Gallipoli. The landing, which commenced on the night of 6 August 1915, was intended to support a breakout from the Anzac sector, five miles (8 km) to the south. "Despite facing light opposition, the landing at Suvla was mismanaged from the outset and quickly reached the same stalemate conditions that prevailed on the Anzac and Helles fronts. On 15 August, after a week of indecision and inactivity, the British commander at Suvla, Lieutenant-General Sir Frederick Stopford was dismissed. His performance in command was one of the most incompetent feats of generalship of the First World War." — Wikipedia Rev Ernest Northcroft Merrington (the photographer), (1876-1953) was chaplain to the Australian Light Horse Regiment. He was a founding father of Emmanuel College.

comment._content: Thanks Pixel Wrangler - I really appreciate the time you've put in with the Anzac Day upload, adding all this textual info: I had no idea about the periscope rifles. -- Courtney

comment.author: 30273252@N02
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called British Army, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 30273252@N02
comment._content: Very interesting photograph for me as my Great Grandfather was killed in action with the 5th Bedfords at Suvla.

comment.author: 54030918@N05
comment._content: I have been researching my family ancestory for many years and have only found out about my paternal grandfather Joseph Bradley from Kilkenny Ireland. He was with the Royal Irish Regiment they arrived at Sulva Bay in October 1915. Thankfully he survived this terrible war, but died in 1935 in Llanelli South Wales United Kingdom. He was only 46 years old, he left a wife five sons and two daughters. My website is www.bradleyfamilytree.co.uk

comment.author: 50074978@N06
comment._content: interesting pictures! My grandfather was there too in october 1915. He, 7th North Staffordshire REgiment was one of the last man who left Gallipoli. He was wounded at that time. He went to Mesopotamia and was a POW in Turkey. He came back in 1919. He was about 53 when he died. Not old. He died after my birth.  The same as Toucheinhands above. They suffered a lot. poor chaps.

comment.author: 25107801@N03
comment._content: Can someone remind us what the hell were the Brits.French.NZ and ass'trilia's business in this area? Was the invasion to oust the turks from middle east oil fields?

comment.author: 86259458@N02
comment._content: A relative of mine (paternal line) Norah Mary Willies was out at Suvla Bay in 1915 as a nurse.  She was part of the QARANC or Queen Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps.  30 mins ago I did not know about her or QARANC or Suvla Bay.  It is thanks to all of the generous people who make the information available that we can find out more.

comment.author: 91977876@N02
comment._content: My father Alastair M. MacLachlan was in the Field Ambulance of the Scottish Horse.He assisted at operations in a dugout on the beach at Suvla Bay. The wounded were then shipped out under cover of darkness to the ships off shore. I find all details of this crazy campaign very interesting.
